title: Variational inequality
text:
In <a href="mathematics">mathematics</a>, a variational inequality is an <a href="inequality%20%28mathematics%29">inequality</a> involving a <a href="Functional%20%28mathematics%29">functional</a>, which has to be <a href="Inequality%20%28mathematics%29%23Solving%20Inequalities">solved</a> for all possible values of a given <a href="Variable%20%28mathematics%29">variable</a>, belonging usually to a <a href="convex%20set">convex set</a>. The <a href="mathematical">mathematical</a> <a href="theory">theory</a> of variational inequalities was initially developed to deal with <a href="Equilibrium%20point">equilibrium</a> problems, precisely the <a href="Signorini%20problem">Signorini problem</a>: in that model problem, the functional involved was obtained as the <a href="first%20variation">first variation</a> of the involved <a href="Signorini%20problem%23The%20potential%20energy">potential energy</a>. Therefore, it has a <a href="Calculus%20of%20variation">variational origin</a>, recalled by the name of the general abstract problem. The applicability of the theory has since been expanded to include problems from <a href="economics">economics</a>, <a href="finance">finance</a>, <a href="Optimization%20%28mathematics%29">optimization</a> and <a href="game%20theory">game theory</a>.
History.
The first problem involving a variational inequality was the <a href="Signorini%20problem">Signorini problem</a>, posed by <a href="Antonio%20Signorini">Antonio Signorini</a> in 1959 and solved by <a href="Gaetano%20Fichera">Gaetano Fichera</a> in 1963, according to the references and : the first papers of the theory were and , . Later on, <a href="Guido%20Stampacchia">Guido Stampacchia</a> proved his generalization to the <a href="Lax%E2%80%93Milgram%20theorem">Lax–Milgram theorem</a> in in order to study the <a href="regularity%20problem">regularity problem</a> for <a href="partial%20differential%20equation">partial differential equation</a>s and <a href="coin">coin</a>ed the name "variational inequality" for all the problems involving <a href="inequality%20%28mathematics%29">inequalities</a> of this kind. <a href="Georges%20Duvaut">Georges Duvaut</a> encouraged his <a href="graduate%20student">graduate student</a>s to study and expand on Fichera's work, after attending a conference in <a href="Brixen">Brixen</a> on 1965 where Fichera presented his study of the Signorini problem, as reports: thus the theory become widely known throughout <a href="France">France</a>. Also in 1965, Stampacchia and <a href="Jacques-Louis%20Lions">Jacques-Louis Lions</a> extended earlier results of , announcing them in the paper : full proofs of their results appeared later in the paper .
